stocks.note: *Numbers as of market close on Feb 18th
stocks.news:
Moderna Gets A Booster

Moderna shares traded higher yesterday after the FDA said it would review the company's flu shot.

‚Ä¢ The decision is a reversal after it originally said it wouldn't accept an application from the biotech company.

Moderna shares are up more than 50% YTD, making it one of the S&P 500's top-performing stocks in 2026.

Cybersecurity Takes A Hit:

Palo Alto Networks (PANW -6.82%) is one of the leading cybersecurity companies in the country.

But the company reported disappointing earnings, sending the stock lower.

Other names, like Fortinet (FTNT -1.22%) also fell on the report.

economy.commentary:
To The Sunshine State:

Palantir (PLTR +1.77%) became the latest corporation to move its headquarters to Florida.

Why? Friendlier taxes for businesses and billionaires.

Citadel, one of the largest hedge funds in the world, also moved its HQ to Miami in recent years.

Back To Basics:

JPMorgan (JPM +0.54%) announced it's going back to basics: more in-person banks.

The company said it plans to open more than 160 new branches in 30 U.S. states by the end of this year.

Why? In a world of growing AI adoption, people still want real people handling their finances.

Stablecoins Spreading:

Nigeria and South Africa are leading the world in stablecoin demand according to a new survey.

‚Ä¢ 80% of respondents in those countries hold stablecoins, and 75% plan to buy more.

Stablecoins like USDC offer faster, more reliable payments, as well as lower fees.

While citizens like the option, central banks worry this trend gives them less control over the economy.

real_estate.homebuilder:
üóûÔ∏è Breaking Today: NAR Pending Home Sales:

The National Association of Realtors (NAR) released their Pending Home Sales Report this morning, showing a 0.8% month-over-month dip.

Despite mortgage rates stabilizing near 6%‚Äîwhich theoretically qualifies millions more buyers than last year‚Äîmany buyers are still holding off because of painfully low housing supply, a dynamic heavily impacting the Bay Area.

Lowest Rates In Years:

Mortgage rates are close to their lowest point in years, leading to a jump in refinance applications.

Borrowers are reworking their loans to take advantage of the lower rates.

But, the drop in rates hasn't led to a surge in buying activity, at least not yet.
real_estate.commentary:
üìç Alameda County (Stabilized but Seller-Leaning)

The market is a bit more balanced compared to Santa Clara, though still favoring sellers. The county-wide median sale price is currently around $925,000 to $1.04M.

Homes are taking a little longer to sell here (around 28 to 43 days on average), giving buyers slightly more breathing room to negotiate, especially on higher-end luxury inventory or properties that need work.

However, move-in ready homes in key commuter locations are still fetching top dollar and moving quickly.

‚Ä¢ New Housing Legislation: Assemblymember Alex Lee (D-Milpitas) just introduced AB 1997. This bill aims to speed up the permitting process for housing developments at the local level by requiring cities to appoint project development managers to fast-track approvals.

‚Ä¢ City Leadership & Budget: The Fremont City Council recently approved a budget rebalancing measure to keep local services running smoothly. Meanwhile, the Fremont Police Department announced that Chief Sean Washington will be retiring after 28 years of distinguished service.

‚Ä¢ Tahoe Avalanche: The Bay Area is mourning alongside the rest of Northern California after a devastating avalanche near Lake Tahoe's Castle Peak area left 8 backcountry skiers dead, with one still missing.

‚Ä¢ Super Bowl Boost: Recent reports indicate that the Super Bowl brought a significant economic boost to both Santa Clara and San Jose, driving record ridership on South Bay public transit.

Everything's Bigger In Texas:

A San Antonio investor pleaded guilty to a charge related to a real estate Ponzi scheme.

He raised more than $60M and paid some investors what he said was interest payments on the properties, but was really just money from other investors.
